translated: The Tiantai Zhizhe Dashi said
The second part has 165 lines of verse, divided into two parts: the first has
100 lines of verse, praising the above prose section, and the last 65 lines clarify the methods of transmitting the sutra.
The above prose section has an opening analogy and a combined analogy, and the verse also has two parts:
The first has 65 and a half lines of verse, praising the opening analogy;
Next, there are 34 and a half lines of verse, praising the combined analogy.
The first also has two parts:
The first has 33 lines of verse, praising the general analogy;
Next, there are 32 and a half lines of verse, praising the specific analogy.

The general praise has six meanings, and among the six meanings, it praises four of them, and also obtains two of them. The praise of the house also obtains the one gate, and the praise of the five hundred people also obtains the thirty sons.
The first sentence clarifies the elder, which praises the superior position and title, and also obtains the name, practice, and praise of virtue.

Since he has the virtue of an elder, he is known by his name and conduct, and is revered by the whole country and city. It is also known that his inner and outer years and virtue are both high. Internally, the BhagavÄn is his title, and he knows for himself that he is fully endowed with the myriad virtues of wisdom, elimination of afflictions, and compassion.
The second part, three lines and one sentence, praises the second example of the house in the original story, which is divided into two parts:
The first sentence praises the vastness of the house;
The second part, three lines, extensively describes the essence of the house, clarifying the appearance of what is being burned, therefore knowing that this praises the essence of the house.
The three realms without beginning are old, not created now, and impermanent and humble, called extremely dilapidated.
It is also said that the head is the hall, the abdomen is the main hall, and the back is the house. The impermanence of the continuous succession of thoughts is high and dangerous.

One says, the form realm is the hall, the desire realm is the house, not avoiding falling is called high and dangerous, the life root supporting is like a pillar, and past karmic actions are the foundations.
It is also said, the two feet are the roots of the pillars, and the three characteristics that cause change are called decay.
The consciousness that is the maintainer is considered the beams and rafters, and the various sufferings that destroy it are like tilting and slanting.
It is also said, the spine is the beams and rafters, the buttocks are the foundations, and the time of decline and old age is ruinous.

As for the walls, one says, the four elements are the walls, the skin is the plaster, the four deportments being incorrect are disorderly and falling, and the five consciousnesses being dull and not corresponding to the objects are deviations.

It is also said that the walls and fences are dilapidated like the skin wrinkling and decaying, the youthful complexion is fresh and pure like the initial mud plaster, the old complexion is withered and haggard like the later peeling off, the hair and beard are decayed and old, all falling out like the thatch is scattered and falling, the sinews and bones are weak and the joints are not supported like the rafters and eaves are broken and falling apart.
As for surrounding obstructions and twists and turns, the seal master says:

The thirty-six substances obstruct each other, thus it is said 'surrounding obstructions.' The intestines of a pig twist and turn, thus it is said 'twists and turns.' Not only is it subject to impermanence, it is also impure and suffering, thus it is said 'filled with miscellaneous filth.'

Now it is said that surrounding obstructions are the six consciousnesses, and twists and turns are the six sense organs. The six consciousnesses perceive the six sense organs and grasp objects, which is difficult, thus it is said twists and turns. The six sense objects universally taint the six sense organs, thus it is said filled with miscellaneous filth.
The two explanations based on causes and conditions and contemplating the mind are explained in detail.
There were five hundred people - the third, half a line, praises the third above, the parable of the five hundred people.
The spiritual capacities of the three vehicles are included in the five realms, and also obtain the parable of the thirty children.
From owls and hawks below, the fourth, there are twenty-nine lines of verse, which correctly praise the fifth above, the arising of the fire.
This is further divided into four:

First, there are twenty-two verses, clarifying the events on the ground, a parable of the arising of the fire in the desire realm;ğŸ”½Next, the second has three and a half verses, clarifying the events in the hole, a parable of the arising of the fire in the form realm;
Next, the third has two and a half verses, clarifying the events in the sky, a parable of the arising of the fire in the formless realm;
Later, the fourth, one verse, concludes that the many difficulties are not one.
In the arising of the fire in the desire realm, there are further four:
First, seventeen and a half verses, clarifying the burned classes, a parable of the ten afflictions of sentient beings;
The second part, consisting of one and a half verses, clarifies the cause of the fire's arising, which is the cause for the arising of the five turbidities;
The third part, consisting of one and a half lines, directly clarifies the momentum of the fire's arising, which is the arising of the five turbidities;
The fourth part, consisting of one and a half lines, clarifies the appearance of being burned, which is the experience of the eight sufferings and the five turbidities.
In the first part, which consists of seventeen and a half lines, there are two sections:
The first sixteen lines directly clarify what is being burned;
The second part, which consists of one and a half lines, is a concluding summary.
Within what is being burned, there are two sections:
The first six lines clarify the burning of birds and beasts, which is a metaphor for the sentient beings with the five dull afflictions;
The second ten lines clarify the burning of ghosts and spirits, which is a metaphor for the sentient beings with the five sharp afflictions.
The first five dull afflictions are divided into two parts:
The first five and a half lines clarify the five dull afflictions;
The second half line concludes.
Now, the first five dull afflictions are divided into five parts:
The first half line is a metaphor for the affliction of pride.
Sentient beings exalt themselves and look down on others, like birds that naturally soar high and look down.
The eight birds are a metaphor for the eight kinds of pride. The Sutra of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s Questions clarifies the eight kinds of arrogance. Now they are used to match the eight birds.

The arrogance of being in one's prime is like an owl, the arrogance of nature is like an owl, the arrogance of wealth is like a vulture, the arrogance of self-mastery is like an eagle, the arrogance of longevity is like a crow, the arrogance of wisdom is like a magpie, the arrogance of practicing goodness is like a dove, and the arrogance of appearance is like a pigeon. Looking down on others is arrogance, being self-important is pride, self-anger is greed, loving others is lust, being angry with oneself is hatred, and confusing oneself is delusion.
Next, vipers and below, the second two lines, are a metaphor for the affliction of anger.

There are three kinds of anger:ğŸ”½The venom of vipers is strong, and they inhale without being touched, which is a metaphor for unreasonable anger;ğŸ”½Scorpions sting when touched, which is a metaphor for angry attachment to principles;
Centipedes are a metaphor for angry disputes.
The world says that the red-necked one is a centipede and the non-red one is a millipede.
Lizards and below, the third, two lines, is a metaphor for the deluded mind.

Delusion has independent arising and associated arising. The lizards and centipedes are still, metaphorically representing independent ignorance. The weasels, martens, and mice metaphorically represent the associated [delusions].
Various evil insects and below, from the root of delusion, all the bonds arise.
It clarifies that the various deluded minds mutually condition each other, or condition the three realms like intersecting and crossing, and their rapid arising is like running.

Feces and urine and below, one line, clarifies the objects that the deluded mind clings to, which are all impermanent, suffering, without self, and impure. Because of delusion, one does not understand and calculates purity and so forth within them, giving rise to defiled attachment, thus saying the dung beetles gather on top of it.
Foxes and wolves and below, the fourth, two lines, clarify the deluded mind of craving.
Craving is of two kinds:
One is powerful, the other is powerless.
The powerful one takes by force, like foxes and wolves;
The powerless one can only beg from others for coarse and inferior things, like wild foxes.
Chewing and below clarifies the objects of greed, attracting things towards oneself like chewing, not using reason like trampling.
The greedy mind takes objects, sometimes taking a city, sometimes taking a country, with boundaries like nibbling.
It is also said that the greedy mind takes objects with or without use. Taking with use is like chewing, taking without use is like trampling, and also, little is chewing, much is trampling.
Bones and flesh scattered about means accumulating the five sense objects without knowing when to stop.
Because of this, a pack of dogs compete to come and snatch at it means this is powerful greed, snatching at the powerless, referring to kings and thieves.

Famished, emaciated, and frantic means always being dissatisfied like hunger, not being able to obtain what one seeks like emaciation, and various kinds of seeking like franticness. A person with much desire is poor even if wealthy.
The mind of love is greedy for the flesh of the five sense objects;

The mind of views is greedy for the bones of principles. Seeking and investigating knowledge and views eventually leads to many understandings, which are like many bones. Dogs that need bones will compete to pick them up.

Among the various views, not obtaining the food of the true Dharma is called hunger. Being unable to subdue and eliminate views is called emaciation. Seeking understanding everywhere is called franticness.
One says it is the hope and expectation of a greedy person.
Fighting, grabbing, and barking - the fifth two lines - is a metaphor for the hindrance of doubt.
Hesitation between two extremes is called doubt. Not deciding right or wrong is fighting. Thinking it is right is grabbing, and thinking it is wrong is pulling.
Growling and barking means expressing arguments to decide right or wrong.
The two lines fear and terror are the second, concluding the five dull afflictions above.
Everywhere there are and below, the second, with ten lines, clarifies the five sharp afflictions.
It is divided into two parts:
The first half line generally clarifies the sharp afflictions. The sharp afflictions universally give rise to the five aggregates and four truths. The following says everywhere there are.

Ghosts and spirits have spiritual powers and wisdom, while birds and beasts do not. Therefore, the sharp afflictions are likened to ghosts and spirits, and the dull afflictions are compared to birds and beasts.
Yakshas and below, the second, with nine and a half lines, specifically clarify the five sharp afflictions.
It is divided into five parts:

The first three lines clarify the yakshas, which are swift ghosts, likened to wrong views that deny cause and effect. People are good rewards, likened to supramundane cause and effect not mixed with afflictions;
Denying this principle is like eating human flesh.
Poisonous insects and such are evil retributions. Like the various afflictions of cause and effect in the world, denying this principle is like eating poisonous insects and such.
Giving birth to and nursing means that the methods of the world arise from causes of the same kind and give rise to effects of the same kind.
Each guarding its own means that causes can have effects, which is called guarding, and they must be obtained without loss, which is called protection.
Moreover, human flesh is good, and poisonous insects are evil. The mind of wrong views denies good and evil causes and effects, which is like eating.
Giving birth to and nursing generally explains that both good and evil have the function of giving rise to each other through causes and effects.
Having eaten and being full means the mind of views is accomplished.
The evil mind is rampant means the mind of views expands.

The sound of fighting means that when the inner mind is accomplished and the teachings are proclaimed externally, proclaiming the Dharma of no cause and no effect, it can cause the listener to fall into the three evil paths, therefore it is called fear.
Below kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a, the second two lines and two sentences, are a metaphor for attachment to precepts.
KumbhÄá¹‡á¸a is the superior among ghosts, like how contaminated good [deeds] can surpass all insects.
Squatting on a mound means cultivating the ten wholesome precepts can give rise to the six heavens, and the six heavens are the high places in the desire realm, like a mound.

Moreover, non-Buddhists who uphold precepts can cultivate meditation, initially attaining the desire realm samÄdhi, or attaining the future samÄdhi. The future samÄdhi is not yet free from the desire realm, and the peak of the desire realm is like a mound.

Or one foot or two feet away means attaining the concentration of the form realm as one foot, attaining the concentration of the formless realm as two feet, attaining the higher realms as going, falling back as returning, and giving rise to the obstructions of views as indulging in play.

As for grabbing the dog by its two feet, one says that slandering the absence of causes of suffering is like grabbing the dog's feet, denying the existence of the fruits of suffering is like pressing its neck with one's foot, and the roots of the aggregates and the attainment of fruits are like the dog's barking. The sharp views deny the existence of the aggregates and the principle of attaining suffering, causing it to lose its voice.
As for contemplation and understanding, cultivating the six practices to subdue greed, the non-functioning of greed is similar to being cut off and losing its voice;

dogs are desires and greed, the two feet are initial and sustained thought, initial and sustained thought going back and forth always in the realm of greed, counting the breath and stopping the mind is the meaning of being able to bind, which is grabbing initial and sustained thought.

Pounding means that if craving is strong, one should face an impure object and cultivate the contemplation of impurity to subdue craving. Craving is crushed, like a dog being pounded and unable to bark.
It is also said that cultivating the contemplation of impurity is like pounding a dog, and being able to give rise to dhyÄna concentration is like the dog losing its voice from being pounded.
Foot on the neck means that even if a dog is pounded, it may still struggle and not submit, so one should further press down with the foot;

even if one knows that impurity stops craving, craving may still not be completely still, so one should further cultivate the contemplation of impermanence, pressing down with the foot on the neck that clings to permanence, causing fear, and then craving will not arise.
It is also said that restraining the mind in one direction is like pounding it on the ground;
always fixing it on the object is like pressing down with the foot on the neck, preventing it from rising;

A frightened dog is happy by itself means that cultivating the contemplation of impermanence awakens the craving mind, like a frightened dog, and thus attaining the taste of dhyÄna is called being happy by itself.
His body is tall and large - the third, one and a half lines of verse, is a metaphor for the view of the self.

Vertically entering the three periods of time and considering the self to be long, horizontally pervading the five aggregates and considering the self to be large. Considering the self to be sovereign and not cultivating good dharmas is called naked, because of the adornment of evil it is said to be black, and because of the lack of merit and resources it is said to be emaciated.
Those who consider the self do not transcend the three realms, so it is said to always dwell in it.
Considering the self to be in the mind, speaking out and proclaiming the characteristics of the self, is called emitting a great evil sound.
Hoping to attain the fruit of the path through this teaching, it is said to cry out for food.
There are also various ghosts - the fourth, half a line, is a metaphor for the view of grasping.
The throat is narrow, life is in danger, and one cherishes its longevity. Non-thought is impermanent, but it is considered to be nirvana, so it is said its throat is like a needle.
The head is like a bull's head - the fifth, two lines, is a metaphor for extreme views.

Pushing the self to be either annihilated or eternal, annihilation and eternity are like the two horns of a bull's head. Is the body the self, or is the self the body? Based on the view of self, extreme views arise, like the two horns on the head.
The fault of calculating eternity and annihilation is being able to sever supramundane goodness, like eating human flesh.
Being able to sever the roots of worldly goodness is like sometimes eating dogs.
Sometimes calculating eternity, sometimes calculating annihilation, turning back and forth like hair disheveled and disarrayed.
Calculating eternity immediately breaks annihilation, calculating annihilation immediately breaks eternity, like remnants and injuries, fierce and dangerous.
Having no wisdom to nourish oneself with proper food and drink, like being afflicted by hunger and thirst.

Yakshas and hungry ghosts - the second, one and a half lines, summarizes the characteristics of afflictions in the desire realm, and also concludes the characteristics of sentient beings who are purely benefited, which are all defiled minds that are always devoid of the taste of the Way, thus it says hungry and in a hurry.

Peeking through a window clarifies their biased observation of emptiness and longing for the taste of the Way. Although they contemplate, they are stuck in attachment and often do not accord with the correct principle, like seeing emptiness through a window without obstruction.
This dilapidated house belongs to one person - the second, one verse, clarifies the reason for the fire.
The three realms are the place where the Buddha manifests and responds. Since the arousal of the mind, he has vowed to liberate them, thus it says belongs to one person.

The elder in the house can make them careful with fire, but after he goes out the children are ignorant and so cause the fire to start. Internally, this is precisely because the TathÄgata, the Buddha of Great Illumination, always taught them to subdue the five turbidities of sentient beings. When their karmic affinities ended, the TathÄgata abandoned his response. These [sentient beings] later gave rise to the five turbidities. Responding to conditions in other lands is not a permanent departure, so it is said recently gone out.
It is also said that after attaining non-arising, they are not born in the three realms, so it is called gone out. Because they will soon come, it is said recently.
The chapter on the Buddha's lifespan says often manifesting nirvÄá¹‡a, which is precisely the meaning of going out of the house.
The third, two lines below afterward in the house, clearly shows the momentum of the fire starting.

Four sides refers to the location. The body, feelings, mind, and dharmas give rise to the four inversions, five turbidities, and eight sufferings, hence it says at one time. The gradual increase of continuity is blazing. The severance of the life root is exploding. The wind-knife dissecting the body is splitting.

It also says, the sound of moaning in grief and pain is called exploding. The destruction of the faculties is splitting. The cessation of breath, the separation of bones, and the severing of sinews is crushing and falling. The dispersal of the four elements is the collapse of walls and buildings.
The ghosts and spirits, etc. is the fourth, one and a half lines, clarifying the appearance of being burned.
Some say relatives are ghosts and spirits, and crying is raising their voices. Now, the sharp afflictions are used as an analogy for ghosts and spirits.

People with sharp afflictions may either cling to annihilation or permanence. If they cling to permanence, they think dharmas are definitely empty, that once existing they return to non-existence, and non-existence is permanence;

Those who calculate annihilation say that the Dharma is definitely annihilated, and that this one death is without further continuation. They all proclaim it to be definite. The matter has already been made clear, so it is said that they raise their voices and cry out.

If it is dull faculties and various attachments to precepts, they originally do not calculate annihilation. Now, seeing impermanence, they only give rise to fear and doubt, not knowing the method of liberation, so it is said that they are confused and unable to escape by themselves.

Evil beasts and poisonous insects - the second part, three and a half lines, clarifies the matter in the cave, which is a metaphor for the fire arising in the form realm. Various interpretations say that anger pervades the three realms, and this is the text.
The text is in four parts:
The first line clarifies the types that are being burned.

The concentration of the four dhyanas is like a hole. Although it is not as open as outside the door, it still avoids the fierce flames. Entering concentration is still able to avoid the coarse evil of the desire realm.
Beings with sharp faculties also attain concentration, like the piÅ›Äca demons who also dwell within it.
The phrase due to little merit and virtue is the second, the cause of the fire arising. Because of little merit, one approaches evil and encounters suffering.

The phrase being oppressed by the fire is the third, clarifying the power of the fire arising. Although there is no fierce flame in the holes, there is still heat and distress. Although the fourth dhyÄna is without the evil of the desire realm, it also has the subtle suffering of relishing. Therefore, it is said to be oppressed by the fire.

Below mutually harming each other, the fourth, two lines, clarify the appearance of being burned, clarifying the mutual subduing of sharp and dull. The sentient beings with various afflictions attaining dhyÄna are the same, but their calculations are each different. Because of the differences, they mutually argue right and wrong, like mutually harming each other.

Since one gives rise to various views within meditation, one cannot give rise to undefiled concentration and wisdom, but only becomes attached to silence like drinking blood and attached to the five branches like eating flesh. Jackal refers to the craving of the desire realm, which has already been severed in the future concentration, so it is said to have died beforehand, and is also called eating. The craving of meditative concentration is like a great ferocious beast that can swallow the craving of the desire realm.

The four inverted views and eight sufferings of the desire realm are like raging flames, and the four inverted views and sufferings of the form realm are like foul smoke. It also refers to the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas, as well as the four elements, skin, flesh, etc., so it is said that they fill the four directions.
The third, two and a half lines of verse below centipedes, illustrates the events in the sky, which is a metaphor for the fire arising in the formless realm.
It is divided into two parts:ğŸ”½The first line illustrates the types that are being burned;
The second line and a half illustrates the appearance of being burned.

Disliking the concentration of the form realm, one emerges and heads towards the formless. Disliking the coarse objects of form, one contemplates formless dharmas, like poisonous snakes and fire burning, emerging from their holes. If so, then anger pervades the three realms.
If one attains the formless concentrations, one necessarily extinguishes the lower objects, thus it says taking whatever is obtained and eating it.
The peak of the non-conceptual is still not free from the various sufferings of delusion, like the head on fire.
The non-conceptual also has the fire of the eight sufferings:
The arising of a different thought in the mind is called the suffering of birth;
The unceasing moment-by-moment change is called the suffering of old age;
The disturbance of the active mind obstructing concentration is called the suffering of illness;
The regression from concentration is the suffering of death;
The inability to attain concentration when seeking it is the suffering of not attaining what one seeks;
The seeking of concentration without attaining it necessarily involves obstacles, which is the suffering of being with what one dislikes;
The four formless aggregates are the suffering of the five aggregates.
One is unable to immediately sever the seeds of the peak of existence, thus it is like the head on fire.
Because there is no outflows, one is afflicted by hunger and thirst, which is still the running around in confusion of samsara.
The house was like this - the fourth, one line, summarizes the many difficulties of the three realms, not just one, concluding the verse on the general parable.
At that time, the head of the household was standing outside the gate - there are thirty-two and a half lines of verse, praising the second specific parable.
The specific parable has four parts, but the praise now only has three.
The first has two and a half lines, praising the elder seeing the fire;
next, the second, has thirteen lines, praising the parable of abandoning the cart and using the cart, first giving the great and then the small;
next, the third, has seventeen lines, praising the parable of bestowing the great cart.
The first two and a half lines praise seeing the fire, which has three parts:
first, the seer; second, what is seen; third, giving rise to alarm and fear. This has all been praised.
First, the head of the household - the three lines are the one who can see. Above it said seeing, now it says hearing, using hearing to replace seeing. Hearing must come from others.
Standing outside the gate directly praises the above I was able to safely escape from the burning house.
Standing means being in the stage of the Dharma body, always harboring great compassion, wishing to save sentient beings, not dwelling in the seat of ultimate emptiness.
The old commentary says that the Buddhas of the ten directions tell Shakyamuni, You have karmic ties with your children in the three realms, and their wholesome roots are about to be extinguished.
It also says that the potential of sentient beings to respond to the Buddha is for the sake of others.
Now it says that the Dharma is the Buddha's teacher, referring to the Dharma of samadhi. This Dharma as the teacher is for the sake of others.
If one enters samadhi, one can then perceive the potential. Samadhi causes the Buddha to see, so it says someone says.
It also says that great compassion is for the sake of others.
The second line and one sentence below Your children praises the fire seen.
Question:
Since the children have not yet left, how did they come in to play?
Answer:
Or it means that they have previously given rise to the aspiration, and are called emerging from the three realms, but then they regress and are called entering.
It is like a person raising their foot to go out the door, but then turns back, which is also called emerging and also called returning to enter.

Moreover, the principle nature is originally pure and not a dharma of the three realms. Due to ignorance, it gives rise to frivolous discourse and then has birth and death, thus it says previously entered due to playing.
Great goodness not yet attached is childish, and ignorance is covered by ignorance.
Hearing this, they are frightened and enter - the third, two lines, praises the above greatly frightened and gives rise to the mind of great compassion.

How to rescue and save - the second, thirteen lines, praises abandoning the cart and using the carriage. There are two parts: first, there are five and a half lines, praising the above unable to save the child.
In the above analogy there is exhortation and warning. In the above combination, there is only the combination of exhortation. Now it only praises the warning.
The admonishing text has three parts, and now the explanation also has three:
First, four and a half verses, praising the above I will speak of the frightening situation and the suitability of the teaching;
Next, The children are ignorant, the second, three sentences, praising the above But they did not accept the admonition;
Playing and not stopping, the third, one sentence, directly praising the cessation of the teaching.
Plan refers to the suitability of the great teaching.
To tell is precisely the meaning of the teaching of the various difficulties and admonitions.
Pointing to the sentence not stopping, praising the above only looking at the father and the meaning of letting go of bitter words.
At that time the elder had this thought, the second, seven and a half verses, praising the above using the carts.
There are four in the above:
First, imagining the three carts;
Second, knowing the children's original minds;
Third, praising the three carts as rare;
Fourth, satisfying the children's wishes.
Now in the praise, there are only three meanings, briefly not praising knowing the children's original minds.

The first three lines of verse correspond to the section on the use of skillful means. The second section, three verses beginning with announcing to the children, praises the rarity of the three vehicles.
Above it clarifies the three meanings of exhortation, demonstration, and realization. Now the verses also have three meanings, with a repeated exhortation making four:
The first line of verse corresponds to the exhortation.
Next, the three lines beginning with sheep carts correspond to the demonstration.
Next, the one line beginning with you should come out again corresponds to the exhortation.
Next, the one verse beginning with I will for your sake corresponds to the realization.
Hearing this about the various carts - the third, one and a half lines of verse - corresponds to the children's fulfillment of their wishes.
Now it generally corresponds to the six lines above. Racing corresponds to seeing the truth above. Empty ground corresponds to the above post-learner stage.

From the elder sees the children escape from the burning house below, the third, there are seventeen lines of verse, corresponding to the above third section on the parable of the bestowal of great carts.
The above text has four parts:
First, escaping from the disaster; second, requesting the carriage; third, equally bestowing the great carriage; fourth, joyfully obtaining the carriage.
Now the verse also has four parts:
First, five lines praise escaping from the disaster and rejoicing;
Second, three lines praise requesting the carriage; third, seven and a half lines praise equally bestowing; fourth, one and a half lines praise joyfully obtaining the carriage.
In the first five lines praising above the sons escaping from the disaster, there are two parts:
First, one line praises escaping from the disaster;
Next, and themselves below, second, four lines praise rejoicing.
Sitting on the lion seat has two explanations:
One says, the sons sitting on the seat, having escaped from the three realms, are therefore fearless;

The second says that the elder sits on the seat. When the elder sees his son escape from danger, he immediately attains fearlessness. Initially, outside the gate, he still has worries and fears, so it is said he stands. Now, having left the gate, he sits fearlessly, so the chapter on skillful means says, Now I am joyful and fearless.
The text on escaping from danger is finished.
And he rejoices - the second, four lines, praises the elder's joy, as in the text.
Knowing that his father is sitting peacefully - the second, three lines of verse, praises the second request for the carriage, as in the text.

The elder is greatly wealthy - the third, seven and a half lines, praises the third, the bestowal of the great carriage above. The text above has two chapters, two elaborations, and two explanations, totaling five texts. Now it only praises four, not the impartial mind, and does not praise the explanation of the impartial mind.

The first line surpasses the fourth verse, which explains the great vehicle. A house is called a treasury, and the ground is called a storehouse. The practice is endowed with all dharmas and is called a treasury. The eyes, ears, and six sense organs are endowed with all dharmas and are called a treasury.
Next, with various precious things, the second, six-line verse, praises the third, the vast vehicle.
The next two lines praise the two chapters. With this wonderful vehicle, the third, praises the second chapter on the great vehicle.
Equally bestowing it on the children, the fourth, praises the first chapter on the impartial mind.
The children at that time were overjoyed, the fourth, one and a half lines, praises the joy of obtaining the vehicle.

Roaming in the four directions means riding the wisdom of the middle way, horizontally roaming the four kinds of four gates and four kinds of four truths, and vertically roaming the forty-one stages, ultimately attaining the virtues of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. Therefore, it is said that one plays freely.
I am also like this and below, the second part, thirty-four and a half lines, is the verse corresponding to the parable.
The first four lines correspond to the general parable, but with four meanings it also includes the six parables.

I am also like this - one line corresponds to the elder. The first half corresponds to the position and title, and the second half corresponds to the name and practice, also including the meaning of praising the virtues.
The seven kinds of skillful means are the most revered among the sages, and the nine kinds are the fathers of the world.
All sentient beings are my children - one verse corresponds to the five destinies, and the meaning also includes the thirty children.
The thirty children are the conditioned children, and all sentient beings are the true children.
